kineticstoolkit.player module¶

Provides the Player class to visualize markers and rigid bodies in 3d.

The Player class is accessible directly from the toplevel Kinetics Toolkit namespace (i.e., ktk.Player).

Classes

Player(*ts[, segments, current_frame, …])

A class that allows visualizing markers and rigid bodies in 3D.
class kineticstoolkit.player.Player(*ts, segments={}, current_frame=0, marker_radius=0.008, axis_length=0.1, axis_width=3.0, segment_width=1.5, zoom=1.0, azimuth=0.0, elevation=0.2, translation=(0.0, 0.0), target=(0.0, 0.0, 0.0), track=False, perspective=True)¶

Bases: object

A class that allows visualizing markers and rigid bodies in 3D.

player = ktk.Player(parameters) creates and launches a Player instance.

Parameters

  • *ts – Contains the markers and rigid bodies to visualize, where each data key is either a marker position expressed as Nx4 array (N=time), or a rigid body pose expressed as a Nx4x4 array. Multiple TimeSeries can be provided, e.g., ktk.Player(markers, rigid_bodies)

  • segments (Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]) –

    Optional. Used to draw lines between markers. Each key corresponds to a segment, where a segment is another dict with the following keys:

    • Links: list of list of 2 str, where each str is a marker name. For example, to link Marker1 to Marker2 and Marker1 to Marker3, Links would be: [[‘Marker1’, ‘Marker2’], [‘Marker1’, ‘Marker3’]]

    • Color: character or tuple that represents the color of the link. Color must be a valid value for matplotlib’s plots.

  • current_frame (int) – Optional. Sets the inital frame number to show.

  • marker_radius (float) – Optional. Sets the marker radius as defined by matplotlib.

  • axis_length (float) – Optional. Sets the rigid body size in meters.

  • zoom (float) – Optional. Sets the initial camera zoom.

  • azimuth (float) – Optional. Sets the initial camera azimuth in radians.

  • elevation (float) – Optional. Sets the initial camera elevation in radians.

  • translation (Union[Sequence[float], ndarray]) – Optional. Sets the initial camera translation (panning).

  • target (Union[Sequence[float], ndarray]) – Optional. Sets the camera target in meters.

  • track (bool) – Optional. False to keep the scene static, True to track the last selected marker when changing frame.

  • perspective (bool) – Optional. True to draw the scene using perspective, False to draw the scene orthogonally.

Methods

close()

Close the Player and its associated window.

to_html5([start_frame, stop_frame, …])

Create an html5 video for displaying in Jupyter notebooks.
close()¶

Close the Player and its associated window.

Return type

None

to_html5(start_frame=None, stop_frame=None, start_time=None, stop_time=None)¶

Create an html5 video for displaying in Jupyter notebooks.

Warning

This function, which has been introduced in 0.4, is still experimental and may change signature or behaviour in the future.

Parameters

  • start_frame (Optional[int]) – Start frame in the exported video. Default is the beginning.

  • stop_frame (Optional[int]) – Stop frame in the exported video. Negative numbers to count from the end. Default is the end.

  • start_time (Optional[int]) – Start time in the exported video. Default is the beginning. Ignored if start_frame is set.

  • stop_time (Optional[int]) – Stop time in the exported video. Default is the end. Ignored if stop_frame is set.

Returns

  • A matplotlib animation object for displaying as html5.

  • Use

  • ——

  • Instanciate the player, then call this method on it – ktk.Player(markers, […]).to_notebook()
